newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish chemical trader Ciech buys two soda plants.
newsitem.headline: Polish chemical trader Ciech buys two soda plants.

text.p: Poland's large state-controlled chemicals trading firm Ciech SA on Wednesday bought 75 percent stakes in the country's two main soda producers for 213.1 million zlotys, the Privatisation Ministry said.

It said in a statement that Ciech, in which the treasury holds 53 percent of shares, pledged to additionally invest 350.9 million zlotys over the next 10 years in the two firms -- Janikosoda SA and Soda-Matwy SA, both in central Poland.
Ciech also promised to increase the two firms' capital by 43.7 million zlotys over the next five years through new share issues and keep employment at the current 3,000 jobs.

Workers of the two companies will get up to 20 percent of shares for half price and five percent stakes will be put aside for a government scheme to compensate former owers for property confiscated by the communist authorities after World War Two.
Ciech, Poland's biggest chemical trader, is earmarked for flotation on the Polish bourse in the first quarter of 1997.
The firm, which employs 750 people, had a net profit of 50 million zlotys against 48 million in 1994. It expects to net 43 million this year.
The foreign trade ministry has prepared a plan to consolidate Poland's state-owned chemical sector companies into a holding group, led by Ciech, but the privatisation ministry opposes the scheme.
France's Rhone-Poulenc was interested in buying stakes in Janikosoda and Soda-Matwy but the privatisation ministry earlier said Ciech presented a better offer.
Janikosoda SA employs 1,600 workers and had a 4.1 million zloty net profit on 155.5 million zloty sales in 1994. No figures were available for 1995.
Matwy SA, employing 1,900 workers, had 5.9 million zlotys of net profit and 155.6 million zlotys of sales in 1994.
